These forms must match their subject. 'She is happy' (correct). 'She are happy' (wrong!). 'They were tired' (correct). 'They was tired' (wrong!).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, the verb "be" is a bit of a shape-shifter, like a superhero with different forms! It has special ways it likes to connect with different subjects. You'll see it as "am" with "I," "is" with "he" or "she," and "are" with "you" or "they." It's like each pronoun has its own favorite "be" word, and we need to make sure they're best friends!

slides.text: Practice makes perfect! Match each subject to the correct verb: 'The cat (sit/sits) on the mat.' Since 'cat' is singular, we use 'sits.' 'The children (play/plays) outside.' Since 'children' is plural, we use 'play.' 'I (am/is) hungry.' 'I' always uses 'am.' Trust your ears: if it sounds wrong, it probably IS wrong!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to be word wizards and practice matching! See how "The cat" is just one cat? That means we need the verb that sounds like it's for just one thing, which is "sits." But "The children" is a whole group, so they need the verb that sounds like it's for a group, which is "play." Listen to how the sentences sound – your ears are great guides!

slides.prompt:
1. Match subjects to correct verbs: The bird (sing/sings). The flowers (grow/grows). He (is/are). They (was/were). The baby (cry/cries).
2. Fix these errors:
   - 'The dogs barks loudly.'
   - 'She run every morning.'
   - 'The children is playing.'
   - 'My friend and I goes to school.'
3. Write 5 sentences with singular subjects and 5 with plural subjects. Make sure verbs agree!
4. In your journal, write the subject-verb agreement rule in your own words with 3 examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put all our new skills to the test! First, we'll match subjects and verbs, like "The bird" needs "sings" because it's just one bird. Then, we'll be word detectives and fix the sentences that have mistakes, like changing "The dogs barks" to "The dogs bark." Finally, you'll write your very own sentences, showing off how well you can make subjects and verbs agree!

slides.text: Subject-verb agreement is one of the most important grammar skills. When subjects and verbs agree, your sentences sound smooth and professional. When they disagree, something sounds 'off' — even if the reader cannot explain why. The rule is simple: one subject = verb with -s, many subjects = verb without -s. Your ears already know this rule — now your brain does too!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child choose the correct verb form for singular and plural subjects? Can they use forms of 'be' correctly (am/is/are/was/were)? Can they find and fix subject-verb agreement errors? Can they apply the rule in their own writing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned all about making subjects and verbs agree, which is like making sure all the players on a sentence team work together perfectly. You practiced matching words, fixed tricky sentences, and even wrote your own. Now your sentences will sound super smooth, just like a pro writer!

parent_notes: Subject-verb agreement is often intuitive for native English speakers — children use correct forms in speech before they learn the rules. This lesson makes implicit knowledge explicit, which helps in writing where agreement errors are more common than in speech. The noun-verb -s confusion (nouns: -s = plural; verbs: -s = singular) is genuinely tricky and worth highlighting. The 'be' verb forms are the most commonly confused: 'they was' and 'we was' are common in some dialects but not considered standard in academic writing. Approach dialectal differences with respect — the goal is adding standard forms to the child's repertoire, not correcting their home language. Practice through reading aloud: correct agreement sounds right, and children can develop an 'ear' for it.

title: Multiplication Tables — The 4s and Building Arrays
description: Students learn the 4s multiplication table using bead bars and arrays. They discover that the 4s are double the 2s (a powerful strategy), practice building rectangular arrays on graph paper, and begin to see multiplication as connected to area.
instructions:
1. Introduce the 4s: skip count by 4: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40.
2. Reveal the shortcut: 4s are DOUBLE the 2s! 2x3=6, so 4x3=12.
3. Build 4s with bead bars: 4x1 through 4x10.
4. Write the complete 4s table.
5. Draw arrays on graph paper: 4 rows of 5, 4 rows of 7, etc.
6. Connect arrays to AREA: a 4x5 array covers 20 squares.
7. Use the commutative property: 4x6 = 6x4.
8. Practice quick recall of 2s, 3s, and 4s together.
9. Mixed word problems using 2s, 3s, and 4s.
10. Update the multiplication progress chart.

slides.heading: The 4s Table
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for our new math adventure! We're going to learn all about multiplying by 4 today. The words "Double the 2s" are a super hint about a really cool trick we'll learn to make memorizing these numbers much easier.

slides.setup_instructions: The 4s strategy is powerful: since 4 = 2 x 2, every 4s fact is double the corresponding 2s fact. Have the 2s table visible for reference. Graph paper is essential for this lesson — arrays drawn on graph paper naturally connect to the concept of area.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this lesson! We have these colorful bead bars – the ones with 4 beads on them will be perfect for showing groups of four. We'll also use graph paper, which has lots of little squares, and colored pencils to draw on it. Your math notebook is where you'll write things down, and we have a multiplication chart to fill in as we learn. These are all important for seeing how multiplication works!

slides.text: Time for the 4s! Skip count: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 28, 32, 36, 40. Here is a POWER STRATEGY: the 4s are exactly DOUBLE the 2s. You know 2x3=6, so 4x3 is DOUBLE that: 12! You know 2x7=14, so 4x7 is DOUBLE: 28! This works for every 4s fact because 4 is 2+2 or 2x2.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get ready for the 4s! We're going to start by counting by fours: 4, 8, 12, and so on, all the way up to 40. Here's that super strategy the title mentioned: multiplying by 4 is the same as doubling the answer for multiplying by 2! So, if you know 2 times 3 is 6, then 4 times 3 is double that, which is 12. Isn't it neat how math has shortcuts?

slides.text: Build with bead bars: 4x1 = one bar of 4 = 4. Check: double 2x1=2, doubled = 4. Correct! 4x5 = five bars of 4 = 20. Check: double 2x5=10, doubled = 20. Correct! This doubling strategy means if you KNOW the 2s table, you automatically KNOW the 4s table. Math is full of shortcuts like this!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to use our bead bars! We'll take out bars that have 4 beads on them to show multiplication. For example, 4 times 1 means one group of 4 beads, which is just 4. Then we check our trick: 2 times 1 is 2, and double 2 is 4 – it works! We'll do this for other numbers, like 4 times 5, which is five groups of 4 beads, making 20.

slides.text: Now draw ARRAYS on graph paper. Color a rectangle that is 4 squares tall and 5 squares wide. Count the total squares: 20! That is 4 x 5 = 20. This is actually AREA — the number of square units inside a rectangle! When you multiply length times width, you get area. Multiplication is not just about groups — it is about SPACE too.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get creative with graph paper! We're going to draw rectangles using the squares. Imagine coloring in a rectangle that is 4 squares tall and 5 squares wide. When we count all those colored squares, we find there are 20! This shows us that multiplication can also measure the space inside a shape, which is called area.

slides.text: Let us put all our tables together: 2s, 3s, and 4s. With the commutative property, you know even more facts! 4x3=12 means you also know 3x4=12. Let us do a rapid-fire challenge: 2x5? 3x4? 4x7? 2x9? 3x6? 4x8? The more you practice, the faster these facts come to mind. You are building a multiplication SUPERPOWER!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put all our math powers together! We know the 2s and 3s tables, and now the 4s. We can even use a cool idea called the commutative property: if 4 times 3 is 12, then 3 times 4 is also 12! We'll do a super-fast challenge to see how quickly you can answer questions using all the tables we know so far.

slides.prompt:
1. Write the complete 4s table: 4x1 through 4x10.
2. Test the doubling strategy: write the 2s fact and double it to get the 4s fact for each.
3. Draw these arrays on graph paper and find the area: 4x3, 4x6, 4x8, 4x10.
4. Mixed practice: solve 2x8, 3x5, 4x7, 3x9, 2x6, 4x4 (use any strategy).
5. Word problems: A car has 4 wheels. How many wheels on 9 cars? A dog has 4 legs. How many legs on 6 dogs?
6. Color in the 4s on your multiplication chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to show off what you've learned! First, write down all the answers for the 4s table, from 4x1 all the way to 4x10. Then, use that awesome doubling trick to check your work by doubling the 2s facts. Next, draw those rectangles on your graph paper and count the squares to find the area for a few different sizes. Finally, solve some mixed-up problems and word problems to practice everything!

slides.text: The 4s table comes easily when you use the doubling strategy: just double the 2s! You also discovered that arrays on graph paper show AREA — multiplication measures space, not just groups. With 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, and 10s under your belt, you know a HUGE portion of the multiplication table. You are well on your way to mastery!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite the 4s table? Can they use the doubling-the-2s strategy? Can they draw arrays on graph paper and connect them to area? Can they mix 2s, 3s, and 4s facts in rapid practice?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned the 4s multiplication table by using the clever trick of doubling the 2s, and you even saw how multiplication helps us measure space with area. Knowing the 2s, 3s, and 4s tables really well means you're becoming a multiplication superstar and you've mastered a big part of math!

parent_notes: The doubling strategy (4s = double the 2s) is a genuine mathematical insight, not a trick. It demonstrates the RELATIONSHIP between multiplication facts, which is far more valuable than rote memorization. Similarly, the 8s table will later be double the 4s. This pattern of relationships makes the entire multiplication table learnable through understanding rather than brute memorization. The array-to-area connection is important: it shows that multiplication has geometric meaning, not just arithmetic meaning. Graph paper makes this connection visible. Encourage your child to look for multiplication in the real world: tiles on a floor (array!), eggs in a carton (2x6=12), windows on a building (rows x columns). The more connections they make, the deeper their understanding becomes.

title: Ancient Egypt — Pharaohs, Pyramids, and Daily Life
description: Students explore the social structure of ancient Egypt, from the pharaoh at the top to farmers at the base. They learn about the pyramids as tombs for the pharaohs, daily life along the Nile, and the Egyptian belief in the afterlife that drove much of their culture.
instructions:
1. Review: Egypt's dependence on the Nile.
2. Introduce the PHARAOH: king, god, and leader all in one.
3. Draw the social pyramid: pharaoh, priests/nobles, scribes, soldiers, craftsmen, farmers.
4. The PYRAMIDS: massive tombs built for pharaohs.
5. Show images of the Great Pyramid of Giza — marvel at its size.
6. Daily life: farmers, bread-making, fishing, crafts, games.
7. The afterlife: Egyptians believed life continued after death.
8. Mummification: preserving the body for the afterlife.
9. Students draw the social pyramid and label each level.
10. Write a day-in-the-life diary entry as an Egyptian child.
materials_needed: Images of pyramids and Egyptian art
Model or diagram of social pyramid

slides.heading: Ancient Egypt
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the title slide for our adventure into Ancient Egypt. It tells us we're going to learn all about the super-important pharaohs, the giant pyramids they built, and what life was like for everyone who lived there a long, long time ago. Get ready to travel back in time!

items: Images of Great Pyramid, Sphinx, Egyptian art
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare images of the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Sphinx, Egyptian tomb paintings showing daily life, and cross-section diagrams of pyramids. A model pyramid (built from blocks or cardboard) helps children grasp the scale. Statistics to share: the Great Pyramid used 2.3 million stone blocks, each weighing 2.5 tons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our Egyptian journey. We've got pictures of the amazing Great Pyramid and the Sphinx, plus Egyptian art to look at. You'll need your drawing paper and colored pencils to make your own Egyptian art, and your history journal to write in. We also have a special diagram to help us understand how Egyptian society was built, like a pyramid itself!

slides.text: At the very top of Egyptian society stood the PHARAOH — not just a king, but believed to be a living GOD. The pharaoh owned all the land, commanded the army, and was responsible for the Nile's floods (through prayers to the gods). Below the pharaoh: priests and nobles, then scribes (the educated writers), soldiers, craftsmen and merchants, and at the base: FARMERS — the vast majority of the population.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part explains who was in charge in Ancient Egypt. At the very, very top was the PHARAOH – they weren't just a king, but thought to be a god! Everyone else, from priests and scribes who could write, to soldiers, builders, and most importantly, the farmers who grew the food, all fit into a special order below the pharaoh. Think of it like a pyramid, with the pharaoh at the very peak!

slides.text: The PYRAMIDS are the most famous structures in human history. They were TOMBS — built to protect the pharaoh's body and treasures for eternity. The Great Pyramid of Giza is made of 2.3 million stone blocks, each weighing as much as a car. It took about 20 years and thousands of workers to build. It was the tallest structure on Earth for over 3,800 years!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to talk about the famous PYRAMIDS! These weren't just big buildings; they were super-fancy tombs built to keep the pharaoh safe for their journey to the afterlife. The Great Pyramid is HUGE – it's made of millions of giant stone blocks, and it took thousands of people many years to build it. Imagine building something so big it was the tallest thing in the world for thousands of years!

slides.text: Most Egyptians were FARMERS. They grew wheat and barley, made bread and beer, fished in the Nile, and raised cattle. Children played with balls, dolls, and board games (including Senet — the world's oldest known board game!). Families lived in mud-brick houses with flat roofs. They wore linen clothing and used kohl (black eyeliner) to protect their eyes from the sun's glare.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us what life was like for most people in Ancient Egypt – they were FARMERS! They grew yummy grains to make bread and even beer, and fished in the big Nile River. Kids played games just like you do, with dolls and balls, and even a really old board game! They lived in simple houses and wore light clothes, and even used eyeliner to help protect their eyes from the bright sun.

slides.text: The Egyptians believed that death was NOT the end — it was the beginning of a new life in the AFTERLIFE. To preserve the body for this eternal life, they invented MUMMIFICATION: removing organs, drying the body with salt, wrapping it in linen, and placing it in a decorated coffin. Pyramids, mummies, treasure — all were preparations for life after death.
slides.mascot_explanation: The ancient Egyptians had a really interesting idea about what happens after we die. They believed that life didn't end, but that there was an AFTERLIFE, a kind of new beginning. To get ready for this, they developed a special process called MUMMIFICATION to carefully preserve the body, wrapping it up and putting it in a decorated coffin, all so the person could live forever in the next world.

slides.prompt:
1. Draw the SOCIAL PYRAMID of ancient Egypt. Make it look like a real pyramid! Label each level: pharaoh (top), priests and nobles, scribes, soldiers, craftsmen, farmers (base). Draw a small figure at each level.
2. In your history journal, write a 'Day in the Life' diary entry as an Egyptian child living along the Nile. What do you eat? What games do you play? What work does your family do?
3. Draw the Great Pyramid of Giza with the Sphinx beside it.
4. Research question: How is the Great Pyramid compared in height to modern buildings?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to create! First, draw your own Egyptian social pyramid on your paper, just like the one we saw, and label each level from pharaoh down to farmers. Then, in your history journal, write a story about what a day might be like for an Egyptian kid – what they eat, play, and what their family does. Finally, draw the amazing Great Pyramid with the Sphinx next to it!

slides.text: Ancient Egypt fascinates us because of its incredible achievements: pyramids that have lasted 4,500 years, a writing system (hieroglyphics) that was used for 3,000 years, and a civilization that endured longer than almost any other in history. From the pharaoh to the farmer, every Egyptian contributed to this remarkable culture. Next week we will explore hieroglyphics and more of Egypt's amazing inventions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the social structure of ancient Egypt? Can they explain what the pyramids were and why they were built? Can they describe daily life for ordinary Egyptians? Do they understand the Egyptian belief in the afterlife?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You explored the amazing world of Ancient Egypt, from the powerful pharaohs and giant pyramids to what everyday life was like for farmers and kids. You learned how they believed in an afterlife and even how they built those incredible pyramids that still stand today. You totally rocked learning about this super old and fascinating civilization!

parent_notes: This lesson covers some of the most captivating content in the entire curriculum. Children are naturally fascinated by pyramids and mummies. The social pyramid exercise helps children understand that societies have structure and hierarchy — a concept they can later apply to other civilizations. The daily life section humanizes the Egyptians: they were not just pyramid-builders; they were families who ate bread, played games, and told stories. Mummification can be presented factually without being gruesome — focus on the PURPOSE (belief in the afterlife) rather than the graphic details. If your child is fascinated, there are excellent children's books on ancient Egypt, as well as virtual tours of pyramids and tombs available online. The Egyptian unit is typically a highlight of the lower elementary year.

title: African Wildlife and the Savanna Ecosystem
description: Students explore the African savanna — one of the most spectacular ecosystems on Earth. They learn about the interconnected food web of grassland herbivores (zebras, wildebeest, elephants) and predators (lions, cheetahs, hyenas), and discover how the Great Migration demonstrates the power of ecosystems.
instructions:
1. Review: What biome is the African savanna? (Grassland)
2. Describe the savanna: warm, seasonal rains, tall grasses, scattered trees.
3. Introduce the herbivores: zebra, wildebeest, elephant, giraffe, gazelle.
4. Introduce the predators: lion, cheetah, leopard, hyena, wild dog.
5. Draw a food web: grasses → herbivores → predators → decomposers.
6. Explain the Great Migration: 1.5 million wildebeest crossing the Serengeti.
7. Discuss: Why do animals migrate? (Following rain and fresh grass.)
8. Explore keystone species: elephants shape the landscape.
9. Students create a savanna food web poster.
10. Write 5 savanna facts in geography notebook.

slides.heading: African Savanna
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about the African savanna and the amazing animals that live there, especially how they eat and who eats them. It's like the cover of a really exciting book about wildlife!

items: Photos of savanna animals and landscape
Large drawing paper for food web poster
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare animal cards or images showing major savanna species. Have a map of East Africa showing the Serengeti, Maasai Mara, and the migration route. The food web concept connects geography to science. Videos of the Great Migration are powerful if available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, get ready to gather your supplies for our savanna project! We need photos of the animals and the grassy landscape to see what it looks like, and a map to find out where the savanna is in Africa. We'll also need big paper and colorful markers or pencils to draw our own savanna scene, and a notebook to write down cool facts. Don't forget the animal cards – they'll help us learn about each creature!

slides.text: The African SAVANNA is a vast grassland stretching across East and Southern Africa. It has two seasons: a WET season with rain that turns everything green, and a DRY season when grasses turn golden brown. Scattered trees (like the iconic acacia) provide shade and food. This grassland is home to the greatest concentration of large mammals on Earth.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains what the savanna is! Imagine a HUGE, sunny park with lots and lots of grass, but not too many trees, and it gets warm all year round. It has a rainy time when everything turns green and a dry time when the grass turns yellow, and it's home to more big animals than almost anywhere else on Earth.

slides.text: HERBIVORES (plant eaters) are the savanna's foundation: ZEBRAS eat the tall, tough grass. WILDEBEEST eat the medium grass. GAZELLES eat the short, new grass. They eat in sequence! ELEPHANTS eat leaves, bark, and grass — and they shape the entire landscape by pushing over trees. GIRAFFES eat leaves from the tops of trees that no other animal can reach. Each species has its NICHE.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're meeting the plant-eaters, called herbivores! See, different animals like zebras, wildebeest, and gazelles eat different heights of grass, and giraffes and elephants munch on leaves and bark. This is important because they are the main food for the animals that eat meat, and they help shape the land by eating plants.

slides.text: PREDATORS keep the ecosystem in balance. LIONS hunt large prey like zebras and wildebeest. CHEETAHS are the fastest land animals — they chase gazelles at 70 mph! LEOPARDS climb trees with their prey. HYENAS hunt in packs and clean up what others leave behind. Without predators, herbivores would eat ALL the grass and the whole system would collapse.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we meet the meat-eaters, called predators! Lions, cheetahs, and hyenas are super important because they keep the number of plant-eaters from getting too big. If there were too many herbivores, they'd eat all the grass, and then there would be no food for anyone!

slides.text: Every year, 1.5 million wildebeest and hundreds of thousands of zebras make the GREAT MIGRATION across the Serengeti in Tanzania to the Maasai Mara in Kenya and back again — following the rains and fresh grass. It is the largest land animal migration on Earth. Predators follow the herds, rivers must be crossed (where crocodiles wait!), and calves are born along the way. It is one of nature's greatest spectacles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, get ready for something amazing! This slide tells us about the Great Migration, where over a million wildebeest and zebras travel together across Africa to find fresh grass and water. It's like the biggest road trip ever, and lots of predators follow along, hoping for a meal!

slides.prompt:
Create a SAVANNA FOOD WEB poster:
1. Draw a savanna landscape background (golden grass, acacia trees, blue sky).
2. Draw or paste images of at least 6 animals: 3 herbivores and 3 predators.
3. Draw ARROWS showing who eats whom: grass → zebra → lion, etc.
4. Include decomposers (vultures, dung beetles) that clean up after everyone.
5. Label each animal and its role (herbivore, predator, or decomposer).
6. In your notebook: Draw the Great Migration route on a map of East Africa.
7. Write: Why is the savanna food web like a balancing act?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be an artist and a scientist! First, draw a picture of the savanna with grass and trees. Then, draw or glue pictures of at least six animals – three that eat plants and three that eat meat. Next, draw arrows to show who eats whom, like grass leading to a zebra, and a zebra leading to a lion. Don't forget to add the cleanup crew like vultures and dung beetles, and label everything! Then, find East Africa on your map and draw the path the wildebeest take. Finally, think about why this whole food chain is like a balancing act.

slides.text: The African savanna is a living tapestry where every species plays a role. Remove the lions and herbivores overpopulate. Remove the elephants and forests take over the grassland. Remove the grass and everything collapses. This interconnected web of life is called an ECOSYSTEM, and the savanna is one of Earth's most spectacular examples. Protecting it means protecting EVERY part — from the tiniest dung beetle to the largest elephant.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 herbivores and 3 predators of the African savanna? Can they explain a simple food web? Can they describe the Great Migration? Do they understand why each species is important?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide reminds us how everything in the savanna is connected, like a big family! If one animal disappears, it can cause problems for everyone else, which is why we call it an ecosystem. It's super important to protect all the animals, big and small, to keep the savanna healthy and amazing!

parent_notes: The African savanna lesson brings together geography and science through the concept of ecosystems and food webs. Children are naturally fascinated by African wildlife — channel this interest toward understanding ecological relationships. The food web concept is more sophisticated than a food chain: it shows that multiple species are interconnected, creating resilience. The Great Migration is awe-inspiring and well-documented in video (the BBC's Planet Earth and Africa series have spectacular footage). The concept of keystone species (like elephants) teaches that some organisms have outsized influence on their ecosystem. This is a good time to discuss conservation: many savanna species are threatened by habitat loss and poaching.

title: Read Aloud — The One and Only Ivan, Chapters 21-30
description: Students continue reading as Ivan begins to find his purpose. Stella's health worsens, and Ivan's art takes on new meaning. Students discuss themes of loss, memory, and how caring for others can transform us even when we feel powerless.
instructions:
1. Review: What promise did Ivan make? Why?
2. Read chapters 21-30 with appropriate emotion.
3. Discuss Stella's worsening condition — handle sensitively.
4. Notice how Ivan's art is changing: what is he drawing now?
5. How does Ruby respond to her new home?
6. Discuss: Can art communicate what words cannot?
7. Talk about grief: what happens when we lose someone we love?
8. Notice Bob's loyalty and practical wisdom.
9. Students write a letter from Ivan's perspective.
10. Predict: What will Ivan do to keep his promise?
materials_needed: The One and Only Ivan by Katherine Applegate

slides.heading: The One and Only Ivan
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book! It tells us we're going to be reading chapters 21 through 30 of "The One and Only Ivan," and it hints that Ivan is starting to figure out what's really important to him, his "purpose." It's exciting to see how characters grow and change, isn't it?

slides.setup_instructions: These chapters contain the story's most emotional moments. Stella's fate becomes clear. Be prepared for strong emotional responses from children. Have tissues available. The discussion of loss should be handled with warmth and sensitivity, allowing children to share feelings if they choose.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us what we need for our reading adventure today. We have the book, "The One and Only Ivan," of course, and then some drawing paper and colored pencils so we can get creative. We also need our reading journal, which is like a special notebook for our thoughts and ideas about the story. The grown-up notes remind us that these chapters might be a little sad, so it's good to have tissues ready, just in case.

slides.text: The story is reaching its emotional heart. Ivan has made a promise to Stella — to protect Ruby and ensure she has a better life. But Ivan is a gorilla behind glass. How can he possibly keep this promise? As we read, watch for the moment when Ivan discovers his answer. It comes through the thing he has done his whole life: ART.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important step! It tells us that Ivan made a big promise to Stella, his friend. He promised he would take care of Ruby and make sure she has a good life. But Ivan is a gorilla in a zoo, so how can he do that? This step is asking us to pay close attention as we read to see how Ivan figures out a way to keep his promise, and it hints that his art might be the key!

slides.text: Read chapters 21-30. These chapters are powerful. We see Stella's strength fading, Ruby's innocence, and Ivan's growing determination. Listen for the quiet moments: Ivan remembering, Ivan thinking, Ivan watching Ruby sleep. These are the moments where Ivan is CHANGING — becoming the protector Stella asked him to be.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to read chapters 21 through 30! These parts of the story are really powerful and show us how much Ivan cares. As you read, listen carefully for the quiet moments when Ivan is thinking and watching. These are the times when he's really changing and becoming the brave protector Stella asked him to be for Ruby.

slides.text: Loss is part of every life. When we lose someone we love — a grandparent, a pet, a friend — it hurts. But the people and animals we lose become part of us. Their memory shapes who we are. Stella's memory drives Ivan forward. She may not be present, but her influence is everywhere in what Ivan does next.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide talks about something that can be really hard, but it's a big part of life: loss. When we lose someone we love, like a pet or a family member, it makes us feel sad. But even though they're gone, the memories we have of them stay with us and help shape who we become. Stella's memory is making Ivan stronger and helping him know what he needs to do.

slides.text: Ivan's art is his VOICE. He cannot speak to the humans who visit the mall. He cannot write a letter or make a phone call. But he CAN draw. And what he draws is about to become the most important thing he has ever created. Art can communicate across species, across barriers, across situations where words fail. Watch what Ivan creates.
slides.mascot_explanation: Ivan's art is like his special way of talking when he can't use words! He can't tell people what he's thinking or feeling, but he can draw pictures. This slide explains that his drawings are going to become really important, and they can help people understand him even without words. So, let's watch closely to see what amazing pictures Ivan creates!

slides.prompt:
1. Write a letter FROM Ivan's perspective. Who would he write to? What would he say about his promise, about Stella, about Ruby?
2. Draw what you think Ivan is creating — based on hints in the text.
3. In your reading journal: How has Ivan changed from the beginning of the book? List at least 3 ways.
4. Reflection: Have you ever made a promise to someone? How did you keep it?
5. Discussion: Why is art such an important part of Ivan's story?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to do some fun activities! First, imagine you are Ivan and write a letter to someone, maybe about his promise or his friends. Then, use your colored pencils to draw a picture of what you think Ivan is creating based on the story. After that, in your reading journal, write down three ways Ivan has changed since the beginning of the book. Finally, think about a promise you've made and how you kept it.

slides.text: These chapters show us that even when we feel powerless — trapped, limited, unable to change our circumstances — we can still find ways to make a difference. Ivan's promise to Stella gives him PURPOSE, and his art gives him a VOICE. Sometimes the most powerful thing we can do is express what we feel and hope that the right person sees it.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe how the story has developed? Can they discuss themes of loss with emotional awareness? Can they explain how Ivan's art serves as communication? Do they engage empathetically with the characters?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've reached the end of this part of our reading journey! These chapters show us that even when things seem tough and we feel like we can't do much, we can still find ways to help others. Ivan's promise to Stella gave him something really important to do, and his art gave him a way to share his feelings. It's pretty amazing how expressing ourselves can make a big difference!

parent_notes: These chapters deal with loss — specifically the loss of Stella. If your child becomes emotional, validate their feelings completely. Crying over a fictional character demonstrates deep empathy and emotional engagement, which are strengths. The themes of loss, memory, and purpose are universal and can open conversations about your child's own experiences with loss (a pet, a grandparent, a move away from friends). Ivan's art as communication is a powerful theme: children who struggle with verbal expression may particularly identify with finding other ways to communicate feelings. The letter-writing activity provides a safe way to process emotions through a character's perspective.

title: Linking Verbs and Helping Verbs — The Support Team
description: Students learn about two special types of verbs: linking verbs that connect the subject to a description (The sky IS blue), and helping verbs that work with main verbs to express time and possibility (She WAS running, They WILL go). These verbs do not show action but are essential to complete sentences.
instructions:
1. Review action verbs (run, jump, sing).
2. Introduce LINKING verbs: am, is, are, was, were, seem, become, appear.
3. Explain: linking verbs connect the subject to a DESCRIPTION.
4. Examples: 'The soup IS hot.' 'They SEEM happy.' 'She BECAME a doctor.'
5. Introduce HELPING verbs: am, is, are, was, were, will, shall, have, has, had, do, does, did.
6. Explain: helping verbs HELP the main verb. 'She IS running.' 'They HAVE eaten.'
7. The same word can be a linking verb OR a helping verb depending on usage.
8. Practice identifying linking and helping verbs in sentences.
9. Write sentences using both types.
10. Create a verb types chart in language journal.

slides.heading: Linking and Helping Verbs
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It's showing us that we're going to learn about two special kinds of verbs called "linking" and "helping" verbs. Think of them as a super support team for our sentences, making them stronger and clearer!

items: Sentence strips with various verb types
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence strips showing action verbs, linking verbs, and helping verbs in context. Color-code if helpful: action verbs in red, linking verbs in blue, helping verbs in green. The distinction between linking and helping verbs using the same word (is, are, was) requires careful examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool tools we'll need for our verb mission. We've got our language journal and a pencil to write things down, a whiteboard and markers for practicing, and these special cards and sentence strips. These materials will help us see and sort all the different verbs, like real detectives!

slides.text: We know action verbs: they show what someone DOES (run, jump, think). But some verbs do not show action at all. LINKING VERBS are like an equals sign — they connect the subject to a word that describes or renames it. 'The sky IS blue.' IS does not show action — it LINKS 'sky' to 'blue.' Without it, we just have 'the sky blue' — not a sentence!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step tells us about action verbs, which you already know are super fun because they show what someone or something *does*, like running or jumping. But now we're learning that some verbs don't show action at all! Linking verbs are like a bridge, connecting the "who" or "what" to a word that describes it, like saying "The sun IS bright." See how "is" just connects "sun" to "bright"?

slides.text: Common linking verbs: AM, IS, ARE, WAS, WERE, SEEM, BECOME, APPEAR, FEEL, LOOK, TASTE, SMELL. 'The flowers SMELL wonderful.' 'She BECAME a teacher.' 'The weather LOOKS stormy.' In each case, the verb LINKS the subject to a description. Test it: can you replace the verb with an equals sign? The flowers = wonderful. Yes! It is a linking verb.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are some of the most common linking verbs we'll meet: am, is, are, was, were, seem, become, and appear. They're like the glue that holds a description to the subject. For example, in "The flowers smell wonderful," the word "smell" doesn't show an action, it just links the flowers to how they smell! You can even test it by seeing if you could put an equals sign (=) between the subject and the description.

slides.text: HELPING VERBS are partners that work with a main verb to add meaning. 'She runs' → 'She IS RUNNING' (happening right now). 'They ate' → 'They HAVE EATEN' (completed). 'We go' → 'We WILL GO' (future). The helping verb adjusts the TIME or MOOD of the action. Common helpers: am, is, are, was, were, have, has, had, will, shall, do, does, did, can, could, may, might.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's talk about helping verbs! These are verbs that hang out with another verb to give it extra meaning, especially about time. Like, "She runs" is simple, but "She IS running" tells us it's happening *right now*! The "is" is helping "running" tell us about the present moment. They help make our sentences say exactly when something is happening or if it's even possible.

slides.text: Here is the tricky part: the SAME word can be a linking verb OR a helping verb! 'She IS happy.' IS = linking verb (connecting she to happy). 'She IS running.' IS = helping verb (helping the main verb 'running'). The test: if the verb stands alone with a description after it → linking. If it is followed by another verb → helping. Practice makes this clear!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important part: sometimes, the very same word can be a linking verb OR a helping verb! For example, "She IS happy" uses "is" as a linking verb because it connects "She" to her description "happy." But in "She IS running," "is" is a helping verb because it's working with the main verb "running" to show it's happening now. We can tell the difference by looking at what comes *after* the verb!

slides.prompt:
1. Identify the verb type in each sentence (action, linking, or helping):
   - 'The dog BARKED loudly.' (action)
   - 'The dog IS friendly.' (linking)
   - 'The dog IS BARKING loudly.' (helping + action)
   - 'She SEEMED tired.' (?)
   - 'They WERE PLAYING outside.' (?)
   - 'He WILL BECOME a pilot.' (?)
2. Write 3 sentences using linking verbs and 3 using helping verbs.
3. Challenge: Find sentences where IS is linking and where IS is helping.
4. Create a VERB TYPES chart in your journal: action, linking, and helping with 5 examples each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for some fun practice! On this slide, you'll get to be a verb detective. You'll read sentences and figure out if the verb is an action verb, a linking verb, or a helping verb. Then, you'll get to write your own sentences using these special verbs, and even try a challenge to find sentences where "is" plays both roles! Finally, you'll create a chart in your journal to keep track of all the verb types.

slides.text: Verbs are more complex than they first appear! Action verbs show what happens. Linking verbs connect subjects to descriptions. Helping verbs partner with main verbs to express time and possibility. Together, these three types give English incredible flexibility — we can express exactly WHEN, HOW, and WHETHER something happens, all through verb combinations.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish between action, linking, and helping verbs? Can they identify linking verbs in sentences? Can they identify helping + main verb combinations? Can they explain what each type does?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've learned so much today about verbs! We discovered that action verbs show what's happening, linking verbs connect subjects to descriptions, and helping verbs give extra clues about time and possibility. You did a fantastic job figuring out all these different verb types and how they work together to make our sentences super interesting and clear!

parent_notes: Linking and helping verbs are more abstract than action verbs, which may make this lesson more challenging. The key insight for linking verbs is the 'equals sign' test: 'The cake IS delicious' → 'The cake = delicious.' If this substitution works, it is a linking verb. For helping verbs, the key is recognizing PAIRS: 'is running,' 'have eaten,' 'will go.' Do not push for mastery of the linking/helping distinction in one lesson — this is an introduction that will be reinforced over time. The fact that the same word (is, was, are) can serve as either a linking or helping verb is genuinely confusing; use clear, contrasting examples and revisit often. Focus on recognition rather than memorization of lists.

title: Multiplication Word Problems and Story Problems
description: Students apply their multiplication knowledge to solve word problems drawn from real life. They practice identifying the equal groups in a problem, choosing the correct multiplication equation, building with bead bars or arrays, and writing clear solutions.
instructions:
1. Review: What does multiplication mean? (Counting equal groups.)
2. Present a word problem: 'Each table has 4 chairs. There are 6 tables. How many chairs?'
3. Identify the two factors: number of groups (6) and size of each group (4).
4. Write the equation: 6 x 4 = 24.
5. Build with bead bars or draw an array to verify.
6. Present 8 word problems of increasing complexity.
7. Students solve independently, showing work with drawings or arrays.
8. Include problems with 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, and 10s.
9. Students write 2 original multiplication word problems.
10. Share and solve each other's problems.

slides.heading: Multiplication Word Problems
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our math adventure! It's showing us that multiplication isn't just for math class, but it's something we can use to figure out real things in the world around us, like counting things in groups.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word problems using contexts children relate to: food, animals, vehicles, sports. Each problem should clearly involve equal groups. Include problems from the 2s, 3s, 4s, 5s, and 10s tables. Encourage children to BUILD the problem before writing the equation.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some multiplication fun! We've got these word problem cards, which are like little stories with math puzzles. We'll also use bead bars or counters to build the problems, and graph paper to draw pictures called arrays, and our math notebook to write everything down.

slides.text: You know your multiplication tables. Now let us use them to solve REAL problems! The key to multiplication word problems is finding the EQUAL GROUPS. Ask yourself two questions: 1) How many groups are there? 2) How many are in each group? Once you find those two numbers, multiply them to get the total.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about becoming a multiplication detective! When you read a word problem, you need to look for clues to find the "equal groups." Think about it like this: if you see 3 bags with 2 apples in each bag, you have 3 groups, and each group has 2 apples. Knowing those two numbers helps you find the total!

slides.text: Example: 'A bakery puts 5 muffins in each box. They fill 8 boxes. How many muffins total?' Step 1: Find the groups → 8 boxes. Step 2: Find the size of each group → 5 muffins per box. Step 3: Multiply → 8 x 5 = 40 muffins. Step 4: Check by drawing 8 groups of 5 or skip counting: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a super example to show us how it's done! Imagine a bakery with 5 muffins in every box, and they fill 8 boxes. First, we find our groups: there are 8 boxes. Then, we find how many are in each group: 5 muffins. We multiply 8 times 5 to get 40 muffins total! We can even check by counting by 5s eight times.

slides.text: Some problems are trickier: 'There are 3 classrooms. Each classroom has 4 windows and 2 doors. How many windows in all?' This is JUST about windows: 3 classrooms x 4 windows = 12 windows. The doors are extra information — a distraction! Real math problems often include information you do NOT need. Your job is to find the RELEVANT numbers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes math problems try to trick us, like this one! It asks about windows and doors, but we only need to count the windows. So, we look for the number of classrooms and the number of windows in each classroom, and forget about the doors. It's important to find the information that *really* matters to solve the problem.

slides.text: The best way to check your answer is to BUILD it. Use bead bars: 8 bars of 5 → count to 40. Or draw an array on graph paper: 8 rows of 5 squares → count 40 squares. Or skip count: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40. If all three methods give the same answer, you KNOW you are right!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we learn the secret to being super sure about our answers! We can build the problem with our bead bars, maybe 8 groups of 5 beads, and count them all up. Or we can draw a picture, like 8 rows with 5 dots in each row. If counting the beads and counting the dots gives us the same number, we know we've got the right answer!

slides.prompt:
Solve each problem. Show your work with an array, bead bars, or skip counting:
1. A spider has 8 legs. How many legs on 3 spiders?
2. Each shelf holds 10 books. There are 4 shelves. How many books?
3. A tricycle has 3 wheels. How many wheels on 5 tricycles?
4. Each row in the garden has 4 tomato plants. There are 7 rows. How many plants?
5. A nickel is worth 5 cents. How much are 9 nickels worth?
6. NOW WRITE 2 of your own multiplication word problems. Trade with a partner to solve!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to put on your thinking caps and solve some puzzles! You'll read each word problem, figure out the equal groups, and then use your bead bars or draw an array to find the answer. After you solve them, you get to be the super-creator and make up two of your own multiplication stories for your friends to solve!

slides.text: Multiplication is not just about memorizing tables — it is about solving REAL problems quickly and efficiently. Every time you count equal groups in the real world (wheels on cars, legs on animals, items in packages), you are using multiplication. The skill of reading a problem, identifying the groups, and writing the equation is mathematical THINKING at its best.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify equal groups in word problems? Can they write the correct multiplication equation? Can they verify answers using arrays or skip counting? Can they create their own word problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You used multiplication to solve real-world puzzles, just like a super mathematician! You learned how to spot equal groups, write the right math sentences, and even check your work with cool pictures and counting. Creating your own problems shows you really understand how multiplication helps us count things faster in the world!

parent_notes: Word problems are where mathematics meets the real world. The ability to translate a story into a mathematical equation is a critical thinking skill that extends far beyond math class. The two-question strategy (How many groups? How many in each group?) gives children a reliable framework. The extra information in some problems (doors when asking about windows) teaches careful reading — an important test-taking skill too. Writing original word problems is a higher-order activity that requires understanding multiplication well enough to create scenarios. Encourage real-world multiplication questions at home: 'If each person eats 3 cookies and there are 5 of us, how many cookies do we need?'

title: Pollination — How Plants Make New Plants
description: Students explore the fascinating process of pollination: how pollen moves from flower to flower with the help of bees, butterflies, birds, wind, and other pollinators. They learn about the parts of a flower and why the relationship between plants and pollinators is one of nature's greatest partnerships.
instructions:
1. Review the plant life cycle: flowering is the reproduction stage.
2. Introduce flower parts: petals, sepals, stamen (male), pistil (female).
3. Explain POLLEN: the tiny grains produced by the stamen.
4. Pollination: pollen must move from stamen to pistil.
5. Pollinators: bees, butterflies, hummingbirds, bats, wind.
6. WHY pollinators visit flowers: nectar (food) attracts them.
7. The deal: plants provide nectar, pollinators carry pollen.
8. Dissect a real flower: identify all parts.
9. Students draw and label a flower diagram.
10. Discuss: What would happen if pollinators disappeared?
materials_needed: Real flowers for dissection (lilies or tulips work well)

slides.heading: Pollination
slides.subheading: The Partnership Between Plants and Animals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about how plants make new plants! It tells us the big idea: "Pollination," and that it's a special team-up between plants and animals. Isn't it neat that plants need animal friends to help them out?

items: Real flowers for dissection (large, simple flowers like lilies, tulips, or daffodils)
slides.setup_instructions: Get fresh flowers with visible parts — lilies are ideal because their parts are large and clearly differentiated. Each child should have their own flower to dissect. Prepare a large labeled diagram of flower anatomy. Have tape ready so children can tape flower parts into their journals.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is showing us all the cool tools we'll need for our flower investigation! We've got real flowers to look at super closely, a magnifying glass to see tiny details, a picture to help us learn the parts, tape to stick things in our journal, and our special science notebooks with pencils to draw and write. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather everything!

slides.text: Flowers are not just beautiful — they are a plant's REPRODUCTIVE system. Every petal, every color, every scent exists for ONE purpose: to attract POLLINATORS who will carry pollen from one flower to another. Let us explore the parts of a flower and discover one of nature's most amazing partnerships.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that flowers aren't just pretty to look at; they're actually how plants make more plants, like a baby plant! Everything about a flower, like its bright colors and sweet smell, is like a sign saying "Come here, helpers!" to attract pollinators so they can carry pollen.

slides.text: Look at your flower. The colorful PETALS attract pollinators with their bright colors. The green SEPALS protected the flower bud before it opened. Inside, find the STAMEN — the male part, with a thin stalk (filament) topped by a pollen-covered head (anther). Touch the anther — see the yellow dust? That is POLLEN! In the center is the PISTIL — the female part, with a sticky top (stigma) that catches pollen.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to explore our flower! See those colorful petals? They're like a welcome sign for our pollinators. The little green leaves underneath are called sepals, and they used to protect the flower when it was a tiny bud. Inside, we'll find the stamen, which makes the yellow powder called pollen, and the pistil, which is like the flower's catcher's mitt for that pollen.

slides.text: POLLINATION happens when pollen travels from the stamen of one flower to the pistil of another flower of the same species. But pollen cannot walk or fly on its own! It needs HELP. BEES are the world's most important pollinators — they visit flowers to drink sweet NECTAR, and pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies. When they visit the next flower, some pollen rubs off onto the pistil. POLLINATED!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the magic happens – pollination! It's when that powdery pollen has to travel from the stamen to the pistil, but flowers can't move themselves. So, they get help from visitors like bees! Bees fly to flowers for a yummy drink called nectar, and while they're there, pollen sticks to their fuzzy bodies like glitter.

slides.text: Bees are not the only pollinators. BUTTERFLIES sip nectar with their long tongues. HUMMINGBIRDS hover at trumpet-shaped flowers. BATS pollinate flowers that open at night. Even the WIND carries pollen for grasses and trees. It is a PARTNERSHIP: plants provide food (nectar), and in return, pollinators carry pollen. Without this partnership, most plants could not reproduce — and without plants, most animals could not eat!
slides.mascot_explanation: Bees are super important, but they aren't the only ones who help! Butterflies use their long tongues to sip nectar, hummingbirds zip around flowers, and even bats help flowers at night. The wind can carry pollen too! It's a great deal: the plants give the pollinators food, and the pollinators help the plants make new seeds.

slides.prompt:
1. DISSECT your flower carefully:
   - Gently pull off the petals. Count them.
   - Find the sepals (green, underneath).
   - Identify the stamen (male): count them, touch the pollen.
   - Find the pistil (female) in the center. Is the stigma sticky?
   - Tape each part into your science journal and label it.
2. Draw a large, labeled flower diagram showing: petals, sepals, stamen (filament + anther), pistil (stigma + style + ovary).
3. Draw the pollination process: bee visits flower 1, picks up pollen, flies to flower 2, deposits pollen.
4. Write: What would happen if ALL bees disappeared?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be scientists and dissect our flowers! Carefully pull off the petals and count them, then find the green sepals underneath. Look for the stamens and gently touch the pollen, then find the pistil in the middle – see if the top feels sticky! After you've explored, tape the parts into your journal and draw them, then draw a picture of how a bee helps move the pollen.

slides.text: Pollination is one of nature's most beautiful partnerships. Plants cannot move, so they recruit animal helpers by offering sweet nectar. Pollinators get food; plants get reproduction. This partnership produces the fruits and vegetables we eat — about 75% of all food crops depend on pollinators! Protecting bees and other pollinators is essential for our own survival.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and identify the main parts of a flower? Can they explain the pollination process? Can they name at least 3 types of pollinators? Do they understand why the plant-pollinator partnership is important?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much today about how plants and animals work together! You did an amazing job dissecting your flower and drawing the pollination process. Remember how most of our yummy fruits and vegetables need these pollinators to grow? It’s a super important partnership for everyone on Earth!

parent_notes: Flower dissection is a highlight activity that combines science with hands-on discovery. Children are often amazed to find pollen on their fingers after touching the anthers. The partnership concept (mutualism) is a key ecological idea: both organisms benefit. The bee crisis (colony collapse disorder) is a real and important issue — about one-third of our food depends on bee pollination. This lesson connects to geography (food production), health (nutrition), and environmental stewardship. If possible, observe real pollinators in a garden: watch bees move from flower to flower and notice the pollen baskets on their legs. Consider planting a pollinator garden as a follow-up project.

title: Music — Call and Response Songs from Africa
description: Students explore the rich musical tradition of call and response singing from various African cultures. They learn that call and response is one of the oldest musical forms, practice participating in call and response songs, and discover how this tradition influenced gospel, jazz, blues, and hip-hop.
instructions:
1. Introduce CALL AND RESPONSE: one person sings a phrase, the group responds.
2. Demonstrate with a simple call and response: 'Hey!' / 'Ho!'
3. Explain: this tradition is ancient in Africa — used in work, worship, and celebration.
4. Teach a simple African call and response song.
5. Practice: teacher is the leader (call), students are the chorus (response).
6. Discuss: Why is call and response effective? (Community, participation, energy.)
7. Show how call and response influenced American music: gospel, jazz, blues, hip-hop.
8. Students take turns being the leader.
9. Create an original call and response song.
10. Perform the class composition together.
materials_needed: Recordings of African call and response music

slides.heading: Call and Response
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our music adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about "Call and Response" singing, which is a really special way people sing together, especially from Africa. It’s like saying hello to a new song!

items: Audio recordings of African call and response songs
slides.setup_instructions: Find recordings of authentic African call and response music — West African drumming with vocals, South African choral singing, or East African work songs. Simple call and response songs for children include 'Funga Alafia' (welcome song from West Africa) and 'Che Che Kule' (Ghana). Have percussion instruments ready for accompaniment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our music-making tools ready! We've got some recordings of awesome African music so we can hear what it sounds like. We also have some fun instruments like drums and shakers to make our own rhythms, and a notebook to write down our musical ideas. Make sure you have all these things nearby so we can jump right in!

slides.text: In many African cultures, music is not something you sit and WATCH — it is something everyone DOES together. One of the oldest musical forms is CALL AND RESPONSE: a leader sings a phrase (the CALL), and everyone else sings back (the RESPONSE). It is like a musical conversation between one voice and many voices.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains that in Africa, music is all about joining in, not just listening! It's called "call and response," where one person sings a line, called the "call," and then everyone else sings back the answer, called the "response." Think of it like a musical game of tag where voices chase each other!

slides.text: Call and response has been used for thousands of years in Africa: during WORK (field songs kept everyone in rhythm), in WORSHIP (religious ceremonies with chanting), in CELEBRATION (festivals, weddings, gatherings), and in STORYTELLING (the griot — a storyteller-musician — would call, and the audience would respond). It brings people TOGETHER through music.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, call and response is super old and important in Africa! People used it for all sorts of things, like singing together while they worked to keep a good rhythm, during special ceremonies, at big parties, and even when telling stories. It’s a way for everyone to feel connected and be part of something special.

slides.text:
Let us try it! I will sing the CALL, and you sing the RESPONSE. Listen first, then join in:
Call: 'Che che kule!' (CHAY-chay KOO-lay)
Response: 'Che che kule!'
Call: 'Che che kofi sa!' (CHAY-chay KOH-fee SAH)
Response: 'Che che kofi sa!'
This is a children's song from GHANA. Add the hand motions: hands on head, hands on shoulders, hands on waist, hands on knees!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to try it! I'm going to sing the "call" part, and I want you to sing the "response" part back to me. Listen closely to me first, and then sing with me: I'll sing 'Che che kule!' and you sing it back! Then we'll try the next part and add some fun hand motions!

slides.text: When Africans were brought to the Americas, they carried their music with them. Call and response became the foundation of GOSPEL music (preacher calls, congregation responds), BLUES (singer calls, guitar responds), JAZZ (soloist calls, band responds), and HIP-HOP (rapper calls, crowd responds). So when you hear modern music, you are hearing echoes of African traditions that are thousands of years old!
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? This amazing call and response music traveled all the way from Africa with people to America, and it became the heart of music like Gospel, Blues, Jazz, and even Hip-Hop! So, when you hear those kinds of songs, you’re hearing echoes of music that’s been around for thousands of years.

slides.prompt:
1. Practice 'Che Che Kule' with hand motions until the whole group can do it together.
2. Take turns being the LEADER: make up a call, and the group echoes your response.
3. CREATE your own call and response song:
   - Choose a topic (weather, animals, food, school).
   - Write a 4-line call and response (Leader sings line 1, Group responds with line 2, etc.).
   - Add a rhythm pattern with percussion instruments.
4. PERFORM your creation for the group.
5. In your music notebook: Draw the journey of call and response from Africa to American music styles.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to be the musicians! We’ll practice our song and hand motions until we're super good at it. Then, you get to be the leader and make up your own calls, and we’ll respond! We’ll even try to write our own call and response song about something fun and play it together with our instruments.

slides.text: Call and response reminds us that music is fundamentally about CONNECTION. One voice reaches out, and many voices answer back. This ancient African tradition has traveled across oceans and centuries to become part of the music you hear every day. Next time you hear a song where the singer says something and the crowd or chorus responds — you are hearing the voice of Africa.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what call and response is? Can they participate in a call and response song? Can they name at least 2 American music genres influenced by African call and response? Can they take a turn as the leader?
slides.mascot_explanation: We’ve learned that call and response is all about connecting with each other through music, like a big musical conversation! It started in Africa a long, long time ago but now you can hear its echoes in so much of the music we listen to today. Isn't it amazing how music can travel so far and still sound so great?

parent_notes: Call and response connects music to African geography and history in a participatory, joyful way. Every child can participate — no musical training required. The connection from African musical traditions to gospel, blues, jazz, and hip-hop is historically accurate and culturally important: it shows how African cultural contributions have shaped American and global music. 'Che Che Kule' is a well-known children's song from Ghana with hand motions — videos are widely available online for reference. The creation of an original call and response song develops musical creativity and confidence. Consider exploring more African music: Ladysmith Black Mambazo (South Africa), Youssou N'Dour (Senegal), or Angelique Kidjo (Benin) offer accessible entry points for families.

title: Sewing Skills — Threading a Needle and Running Stitch
description: Students learn the foundational sewing skills of threading a needle, tying a knot, and creating a basic running stitch. Sewing develops fine motor control, patience, concentration, and practical independence — core values of Montessori education.
instructions:
1. Discuss: Why is sewing a valuable skill? (Mending, creating, self-sufficiency.)
2. Introduce sewing tools: needle, thread, fabric, scissors, pincushion.
3. Safety rules: respect the needle, always know where it is.
4. Demonstrate threading a needle: wet the thread end, push through the eye.
5. Demonstrate tying a knot at the thread end.
6. Introduce the RUNNING STITCH: up through fabric, across the top, back down.
7. Students practice on burlap or felt (large holes, easy to sew).
8. Create a straight line of stitches, then a curved line.
9. Practice making stitches even and consistent.
10. Sew a simple shape: a heart, star, or initial letter.

slides.heading: Sewing Skills
slides.subheading: Threading, Knotting, and the Running Stitch
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It's telling us that we're going to learn all about sewing, and specifically, how to get the thread through the needle, how to tie a knot so it doesn't slip out, and how to make a super basic stitch called the running stitch.

items: Thick embroidery thread or thin yarn
Pencil for marking designs on fabric
slides.setup_instructions: Use blunt tapestry needles — they are large enough for small hands and have big eyes for easy threading. Felt is ideal because it does not fray and holds stitches well. Cut thread to arm's length (about 18 inches) — longer thread tangles. Mark simple designs on felt with pencil for children to stitch along. Have extra needles threaded for quick replacement if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Whoa, look at all these cool tools! We've got needles that are nice and big with big holes, called the 'eye', so they're easier to thread. Then there's this colorful thread or yarn, which is like the 'string' we'll use to sew. We also have some soft felt or burlap fabric to practice on, and scissors to cut our thread. Don't forget the pincushion to keep our needles safe, and a pencil to draw our designs! You'll need a grown-up to help you gather all these things.

slides.text: Sewing is one of humanity's oldest skills — people have been stitching fabric, leather, and skins for tens of thousands of years. Today you learn three foundational skills: threading a needle, tying a knot, and making the basic RUNNING STITCH. These simple skills let you mend torn clothing, create art, and express your creativity through fabric.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling us how amazing sewing is! People have been sewing for thousands and thousands of years, way before video games or even cars! Learning to sew is like having a superpower because you can fix your own clothes, make cool art, and be super independent. Today, we're going to learn three important steps: getting the thread ready, tying a knot, and making that running stitch.

slides.text: Step 1: THREAD THE NEEDLE. Cut a piece of thread about as long as your arm. Wet one end slightly (this stiffens it). Hold the needle steady in one hand and push the thread through the eye (the little hole) with the other. Pull it through until you have equal lengths on both sides, OR leave one end short for a single-thread stitch. Tie a KNOT at the far end so the thread does not pull through the fabric.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we're going to learn how to get the thread into the needle, which can be a little tricky at first! First, cut a piece of thread that's about as long as your arm – not too long or it gets tangled. Then, you can make the very end a little wet to make it stiff, which helps it go through the tiny hole, called the 'eye', of the needle. After you push the thread through, pull it so there are about the same amount of thread on both sides, or leave one side shorter if you like. Lastly, we need to tie a knot at the very end of the thread so it doesn't slip out of the fabric when we start sewing.

slides.text: Step 2: THE RUNNING STITCH. Push your needle UP through the fabric from the back. Pull the thread all the way through until the knot stops it. Now push the needle DOWN through the fabric a short distance away. That is ONE stitch! Come back UP a short distance later, then DOWN again. Up, down, up, down — a line of small, even dashes. This is the most basic and useful stitch in sewing.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about making the running stitch, which is like drawing a dashed line with your needle! You'll push the needle UP through the fabric from the back, and pull the thread all the way through until your knot stops it. Then, you'll push the needle DOWN into the fabric just a little ways away from where it came up. Ta-da! That's one stitch! Then you just keep going up and down, up and down, making little dashes.

slides.text: The goal is EVEN, CONSISTENT stitches — each one about the same length, with the same spacing. It takes practice! Your first stitches might be uneven, and that is perfectly fine. Sewing teaches PATIENCE and CONCENTRATION. Slow is better than fast. When you reach the end of your line, push the needle to the back and tie a small knot to secure the thread. You did it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Making your stitches look neat and tidy is the goal here! Try to make each stitch about the same size and leave the same little space between them, like drawing a perfectly straight line of dashes. It's okay if your first stitches aren't perfect – sewing is all about practicing patience and focusing really hard. Slow and steady is the way to go, and when you finish your line, you'll tie another knot on the back to keep it all in place. Great job!

slides.prompt:
Sewing practice:
1. Thread your needle and tie a knot. (Ask for help if needed — this gets easier with practice.)
2. Practice a straight line of running stitches across your felt square.
3. Try a curved line — a gentle wave pattern.
4. Draw a simple shape on your felt: a heart, a star, or your initial letter.
5. Stitch along the drawn line with your running stitch.
6. When finished, tie off the thread on the back.
7. Admire your work! Your first sewing project is complete.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super sewer! First, get your needle threaded and tie that knot like we just learned – ask for help if you need it, it gets easier! Then, practice making a straight line of stitches on your felt, and after that, try making a wavy, curved line. You can even draw a shape like a heart or a star with your pencil and carefully sew right along the lines. When you're all done, tie a knot on the back, and admire your awesome sewing project!

slides.text: You just learned a skill that people have used for over 40,000 years! Threading a needle, tying a knot, and running stitch are the foundation of all sewing. With these three skills, you can mend a torn seam, create embroidery art, attach a button, and make simple fabric items. Sewing teaches patience, precision, and the satisfaction of creating something with your own hands.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child thread a needle (with or without help)? Can they tie a knot at the end of thread? Can they create a running stitch? Are their stitches reasonably even? Can they sew along a drawn line?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you just learned a skill that people have been using for thousands of years! You learned how to thread a needle, tie a knot, and make that super important running stitch. These skills are the beginning of everything in sewing, and with them, you can fix clothes, make art, and so much more. You also learned how important it is to be patient and concentrate, and how great it feels to make something with your own two hands!

parent_notes: Sewing is a Montessori practical life essential that develops fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, patience, and concentration. Use blunt tapestry needles for safety — they can push through felt and burlap but are much less likely to prick fingers than sharp sewing needles. Threading the needle is often the most frustrating part; consider having several needles pre-threaded so children can focus on stitching if threading proves too difficult initially. Felt is the ideal beginner fabric: it does not fray, it holds its shape, and the stitches are clearly visible. Start with the running stitch and master it before introducing other stitches (blanket stitch, cross stitch). The key message: this is a real, useful skill, not just a craft project.

title: Verb Review and Action Writing — Making Stories Move
description: Students review all verb concepts from the week (action, linking, helping verbs and tenses) and apply them in creative writing. They write an action-packed story scene, focusing on strong, vivid verbs that make the reader see, hear, and feel the action.
instructions:
1. Quick review: identify verb types (action, linking, helping) in example sentences.
2. Discuss: WEAK verbs vs. STRONG verbs. 'Walked' vs. 'strutted/crept/stomped.'
3. Brainstorm strong verbs for common actions: said→whispered/shouted/muttered.
4. Model: rewrite a bland paragraph using vivid verbs.
5. Writing prompt: An exciting adventure scene (chase, discovery, or rescue).
6. Students write a one-page action scene using at least 10 strong verbs.
7. Underline every verb in the story.
8. Identify each as action, linking, or helping.
9. Peer share: read scenes aloud — do the verbs create excitement?
10. Final copy in language journal.

slides.heading: Verb Review and Action Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our amazing adventure! It tells us we're going to work on making our stories super exciting by using special words called verbs, and the title "Making Stories Move" is a big clue about how we'll do it. It's like giving our stories a turbo boost!

items: Strong verbs word bank (posted or handout)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a 'Strong Verbs Word Bank' organized by category: movement verbs (sprint, dash, stumble, creep), speaking verbs (whisper, shout, murmur, exclaim), emotion verbs (rejoice, tremble, gasp). Display it where children can reference it during writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us the tools we'll need for our writing mission. We've got our language journal and pencil, which is where all our fantastic ideas will go. The "Strong Verbs Word Bank" is like a secret decoder ring for finding awesome action words, and the whiteboard will help us share our discoveries. Make sure you have your journal and pencil ready to go!

slides.text: This week you mastered VERBS: action verbs that show what happens, linking verbs that connect, and helping verbs that add time and meaning. You learned past, present, and future tenses. Today we use all of this knowledge to write an EXCITING story scene. The secret to thrilling writing? STRONG VERBS.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a quick recap of all the verb superpowers you learned this week! Remember how action verbs show what's happening, linking verbs connect ideas, and helping verbs add extra meaning? Well, today we're going to use all those superpowers to write a story that practically jumps off the page!

slides.text: A WEAK verb tells the reader something happened. A STRONG verb makes the reader SEE, HEAR, and FEEL it happening. Compare: 'She walked to the door' vs. 'She CREPT to the door.' 'He said the answer' vs. 'He EXCLAIMED the answer.' 'The dog went across the yard' vs. 'The dog BOLTED across the yard.' SAME action — completely different FEELING.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a super important secret: some verbs are like sleepy potatoes, and others are like zooming race cars! This slide shows us the difference between "weak" verbs that just tell us something happened, and "strong" verbs that make us feel like we're right there. We want our writing to be like a movie in the reader's head, not just a boring description.

slides.text: Replace these weak verbs with strong ones: Instead of 'went' → dashed, trudged, stumbled, raced. Instead of 'said' → whispered, shouted, pleaded, announced. Instead of 'looked' → stared, glanced, peered, squinted. Instead of 'got' → grabbed, snatched, earned, discovered. A thesaurus is your best friend for finding the PERFECT verb.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a cheat sheet for making our writing pop! It gives us examples of how to swap out those sleepy verbs for exciting ones. Instead of just saying someone 'went' somewhere, we can say they 'dashed' or 'trudged' – see how much more interesting that is? We'll use this to find the perfect action words for our own stories.

slides.text: Now YOU write an action scene. Choose a situation: a chase through a forest, discovering a hidden treasure, rescuing an animal, or an adventure of your own invention. Use at least 10 STRONG verbs — no 'went,' 'said,' or 'got' allowed! Mix your tenses if the story calls for it. After writing, go back and underline every verb, labeling each as action (A), linking (L), or helping (H).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super storyteller! This slide is giving you the prompt: imagine an exciting scene like a chase or finding treasure. Your mission is to write about it using at least 10 super strong verbs, and no boring ones like 'went' or 'said'! After you write, you'll go back and mark all the verbs, telling us if they're action, linking, or helping.

slides.prompt:
Write a one-page ACTION SCENE (8-12 sentences):
1. Choose your scenario: chase, discovery, rescue, or your own idea.
2. Use at least 10 strong, vivid verbs (check the word bank!).
3. Include at least one sentence in past tense, one in present, and one with a helping verb.
4. NO weak verbs: replace 'went' with something better, replace 'said' with something specific.
5. After writing, underline every verb and label it: A (action), L (linking), or H (helping).
6. Read your scene aloud to a partner. Does it sound exciting?
7. Revise: can any verb be made stronger?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the main event – writing your own action scene!
